title: ICQ
overview: ICQ launches as one of the first widely adopted instant messaging platforms, introducing features like user IDs, online presence, and message history.

title: MSN Messenger
overview: Microsoft launches MSN Messenger, later rebranded as Windows Live Messenger, dominating instant messaging through the 2000s.

title: Skype
overview: Skype introduces free VoIP calling and instant messaging, disrupting traditional telecom services and enabling global communication.

title: WhatsApp
overview: WhatsApp is founded, providing a mobile-first messaging platform that quickly becomes the dominant global chat app.

title: Facebook Messenger
overview: Facebook separates its messaging feature into a standalone app, growing into one of the most widely used chat platforms worldwide.

title: WeChat
overview: Tencent’s WeChat becomes China’s 'super app', combining messaging, payments, and social features into a single platform with over a billion users.

title: Telegram
overview: Telegram launches with encrypted, cloud-based chats and large group features, quickly gaining popularity for privacy and speed.

title: Discord
overview: Discord is created for gamers with voice, video, and chat, later expanding into communities and enterprises as a leading collaboration platform.

title: Signal’s Global Growth
overview: Signal, originally launched in 2014, surges in popularity during privacy debates, offering fully end-to-end encrypted messaging and calls.
